title: CVE-2023-38039: HTTP header allocation DOS

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is an Open Source project providing a library and command-line tool for doing internet transfers

weakness.name: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling

activities.message:
Thank you for your report!

We will take some time and investigate your reports and get back to you with details and possible follow-up questions as soon as we can!

I disagree with the suggestion that this is severity **high**.

Yes, it might use up all available memory for the process, but this will typically lead to the process getting killed. A careful application or system would already feature some means to make sure the application cannot allocate more than a certain threshold.  This "attack" is also very clearly only from a specific URL that is then also very easy to avoid so it does not stick or hurt afterward.

I agree that it has the potential to cause a security issue so I'm willing to accept it as such.

It has very similar properties as CVE-2022-32206 "HTTP compression denial of service" which we set to severity **medium**. (Funnily enough, even NVD agreed with us on the severity level on that one)

I would imagine that a proper fix would just set an arbitrary max of NNN headers per response, where that could be maybe 300 or something ridiculously high and unlikely to ever get reached legitimately.

I would like to handle this issue in the **next** release (probably to be called 8.3.0) and not in the 8.2.0 release that ships on this Wednesday (July 19) to give us proper time to discuss, work out and test a patch and write the advisory.

Hello, after having done further testing on this I completely agree with you on the initial severity being set too high. 

Regarding a potential fix indeed that seems to be the way to go.
While the HTTP specification does not impose a clear limit for a maximum numbers of headers, yes it's practical to set a limit. Either to a max number of headers to receive, or a maximum number of bytes to receive while we are parsing headers.

Here's some limit numbers I could find for popular web servers and web browsers to compare with:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1097651/is-there-a-practical-http-header-length-limit
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3326210/can-http-headers-be-too-big-for-browsers

Time-frame regarding release seems good to me too.

Imagine a server that returns a fine 53130 bytes worth of headers as a redirect to itself. curl could then, when asked to follow redirects, continue to add (allocated) headers until it runs out of memory even WITH this  check...

I could not reproduce this behavior, wouldn't curl free the current request's headers before redirecting itself ?
From what I observe in testing by sending indefinitely to curl
`{start_of_valid_http_request + "Location: 127.0.0.1:80" + (52130 * "a:b\x0d\x0a") + "\x0d\x0a"}`
memory allocation stays stable while curl handles infinite redirections one after the other.

I'll continue testing and keep you updated, perhaps I misunderstood or my tests are biased by an error.

> I could not reproduce this behavior, wouldn't curl free the current request's headers before redirecting itself ?

libcurl keeps all headers for the entire transfer, including the entire chain of redirects, to allow the application to access any of the response headers once the final response is received. So, a very long redirect-chain will use more memory than no redirects at all.

Sorry for the delay, I've been actively testing this.
I've now been able to observe the mentioned behavior (memory growth with redirections). However I could also see that curl already has a maximum redirection limit which is great.
This should definitely be considered to set a reasonable yet safe limit to header lengths, knowing that (HEADER_LIMIT * MAX_REDIRECTION) might be allocated at maximum.

While testing I saw that even if each redirection was sent 52681 bytes, on a system with 8GB ram curl used at its peak 0.5% memory before hitting the maximum redirection limit and stopped itself. Far less threatening than the results obtained prior to this patch suggestion.

Of course there might still be a better solution/fix to this issue, if you need anything from me feel free to reach out.
According to answers linked to above, "256 KB for all headers in one response" is claimed to be the lowest limit in "popular browsers". I have not tried to research this limit further myself.

Since this is a severity medium issue, I've proceeded and made a PR for it. It does not mention any security aspect.

https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/11582

Hello, seems good to me thanks for your work on the fix/PR !
I've done some research to confirm the "common limit" numbers. I've attached the code of the minimal web server (answers on localhost:80) I used to perform this test and used Firefox 115.0.3 as the reference, the code simply sends a HTTP response and headers until firefox aborts the connection.
Seems like they use some kind of dynamic limit, which on my system was around 500KB.
```
Limits observed on different requests :
514576 bytes
645291 bytes
628256 bytes
495376 bytes
504081 bytes
527496 bytes
```

My first advisory draft for this problem:

---

HTTP headers eat all memory
===========================

Project curl Security Advisory, September 13 2023 -
[Permalink](https://curl.se/docs/CVE-2023-headers.html)

VULNERABILITY
-------------

When curl retrieves an HTTP response, it stores the incoming headers so that
they can be accessed later via the libcurl headers API.

However, curl did not have a limit in how many or how large headers it would
accept in a response, allowing a malicious server to stream an endless series
of headers and eventually cause curl to run out of heap memory.

INFO
----

Since libcurl allocates memory on the heap to store each header individually,
the exact number of headers required for this to become a problem will vary
greatly from case to case. As the headers typically need to be transfered over
a network to curl, the available bandwidth will also affect how likely or how
fast this problem can be triggered.

The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) project has assigned the name
CVE-2023-headers to this issue.

CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling

Severity: Medium

AFFECTED VERSIONS
-----------------

- Affected versions: libcurl 7.84.0 to and including 8.2.1
- Not affected versions: libcurl < 7.84.0 and >= 8.3.0
- Introduced-in: https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/4d94fac9f0d1dd

libcurl is used by many applications, but not always advertised as such!

This flaw existed already in 7.83.0 source code but in that release the
feature was still marked **EXPERIMENTAL** and was not enabled in normal
builds. The label was removed in 7.84.0 why we consider that to the first
vulnerable version.

SOLUTION
------------

Starting in curl 8.3.0, curl returns an error if the total size of the headers
in a single HTTP response exceeds 300 KB.

- Fixed-in: https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/3ee79c1674fd6f9

RECOMMENDATIONS
--------------

 A - Upgrade curl to version 8.3.0

 B - Apply the patch to your local version
 
 C - Monitor response headers and return error if too much
 
TIMELINE
--------

This issue was reported to the curl project on July 17, 2023. We contacted
distros@openwall on September XX, 2023.

libcurl 8.3.0 was released on September 13 2023, coordinated with the
publication of this advisory.

CREDITS
-------

- Reported-by: selmelc on hackerone
- Patched-by: Daniel Stenberg

Thanks a lot!
I just notified `distros@openwall` about this flaw as we are one week away from release + publishing.
Published. This issue is now eligible for a bounty claim from [IBB](https://hackerone.com/ibb).

Thanks for your work. The actual monetary reward part for this issue is managed by the [Internet Bug Bounty](https://hackerone.com/ibb) so the curl project itself therefor sets the reward amount to **zero USD**. If you haven't already, please submit your reward request to them and refer back to this issue.

Thanks for the collaboration.
Have a nice day !
